Make a Prediction

  • What is the relationship between the circumference of a circle and its diameter?

Conduct an Experiment

Equipment

  • Several different circular objects
  • String
  • Tape measures or rulers
  • Table to record results

Directions (individually, with a partner, or small group)

  • Measure the circumference and diameter of several circular objects.
  • Record the object name, diameter, circumference, and ratio of circumference to diameter in a table.
  • Look for patterns or relationships between the measurements.

Answers will vary depending on student choice to measure. Possible answers include:

A base of soda can or glass, edge of a roll of tape, clocks, basketball, frisbees, etc.

Also, the pattern across examples is the ratio of circumference/diameter is approximately

Analyze the Data

  • Look for patterns in the table that Describe how to find the circumference of a circle if you know its diameter.

You can find the circumference of a circle when you know its diameter because the ratio of circumference to diameter should be about 3. For example, when the diameter of a circle is 5 inches, its circumference is 15 because 15 ÷ 5 = 3.
• Describe how to find the diameter of a circle if you know its circumference.

You can find the diameter of a circle when you know its circumference because the ratio of circumference to diameter should be about 3. For example, when the circumference is 20 inches, its diameter is 6.67 because 20/6.67 ≈ 3.

Note: Some students will calculate the relationships to more exact quantities. Based on the accuracy of their measures, students can estimate the relationship to be 3.1 (or closer to the value of π) • diameter = circumference.
